stream_context.summary: Kaze primarily worked on designing a new Wing Cap mission for Course 14, which involved brainstorming, debating mechanics, and meticulously modeling a paper airplane asset from scratch. He also briefly reworked an unfitting bridge texture in Course 1 and discussed contributions from team members Biobak, Badub, and Zeina.

development_findings.summary: Course 1 has undergone another rework, specifically focusing on a bridge texture that Kaze felt was unfitting for the world's art style.
The development of the game's hub world is being intentionally postponed until all the main courses are complete.
development_findings.quote: The hub world is going to happen at the very end.

development_findings.summary: A mission in Course 14 involving a paper airplane on a fixed path was scrapped because it felt too restrictive and contrary to the level's theme of freedom.
The scrapped paper airplane mission is being replaced with a Wing Cap-focused star to give players the freedom to fly across the entire level, creating a feeling of openness.
Kaze is concerned about performance in the visually dense Course 14, particularly due to overdraw, and has begun preliminary optimizations.
Kaze modeled a paper airplane from scratch in Blender during the stream, using a real-life paper model he folded for reference to ensure the folds and geometry were accurate.
A new enemy concept, 'fortune teller' piranha plants that emerge from the ground, was suggested by a community member and added to the project's to-do list.
Kaze identified and live-debugged issues with the flying camera, which was not tilting or behaving as intended, making it difficult to control the Wing Cap.
development_findings.quote: The camera is totally wrong. I don't like this camera at all.

context_findings.summary: Kaze's core design philosophy for the game's later levels is to provide the player with a sense of freedom and immersion, moving beyond the tutorial aspects of the initial course.
context_findings.quote: The purpose of almost all the levels is just to let you experience freedom and immersion at this point after the first one, which has to also teach you movement.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes that creating a strong contrast in gameplay mechanics, such as restricting movement before granting the Wing Cap, enhances the player's emotional experience of freedom.
context_findings.quote: Contrast is really what amplifies your feeling and by having a strong contrast between non-free and free parts, the freedom is going to feel more freedom, you know what I mean?

context_findings.summary: Kaze jokingly expresses a defiant and anti-corporate stance towards Nintendo regarding potential legal action against the project.
context_findings.quote: Nintendo should be scared I attack headquarters.

context_findings.summary: Kaze prefers the N64 development environment for its speed compared to modern engines like Unreal, which he finds slow to boot and compile.
context_findings.quote: Developing in a modern game engine is a lot slower. Like booting Unreal Engine takes minutes or compiling C++ code in Unreal Engine.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is critical of mission designs that lack clear purpose or engaging gameplay, such as randomly scattered collectibles with no narrative or structural justification.
context_findings.quote: Why would someone want to do a mission that's just walk everywhere, idiot?

context_findings.summary: When discussing video game lore from leaks, Kaze believes that if content was cut and never released in the final game, it should not be considered canon.
context_findings.quote: I've heard that this is like random trivia they made up for like potentially to be put in one of the old games and they just didn't put it into the game, which means it didn't really happen.

biobak.summary: Biobak created the new, less pixelated font textures used in the game's UI.
Kaze praises Biobak's ability to rework levels, simultaneously improving visual detail and optimizing performance.
biobak.quote: Somehow every time Biobak reworks the levels, he improves the performance despite adding a shit ton of stuff.

biobak.summary: Kaze compares Biobak to the streamer Northern Lion, suggesting Biobak is very articulate, intelligent, and enjoys word-based games and quizzes.
biobak.quote: Dude, he does all these quizzes. All the words and stuff. And he's good with words. Like you can tell he's really, really good with words. It feels like it's actually Biobak.

badub.summary: Badub has created at least five dynamic songs for Course 14, where the instrumentation fades and changes depending on the player's location within the level.

zeina.summary: Kaze has tasked Zeina with creating a new icon for the ground-pound animation.

key_stories.title: Redesigning the Course 14 Flight Mission
key_stories.summary: Kaze identified that a planned mission was thematically inconsistent with the level's design goals. He pivoted from a restrictive, on-rails concept to an open-ended one using the Wing Cap to better deliver the intended player experience of freedom.
key_stories.challenge: A mission concept for Course 14 involved collecting silver stars while riding a paper airplane on a fixed path, which Kaze felt was too restrictive and contradicted the level's core theme of 'freedom and immersion'.
key_stories.process: Kaze articulated why the original idea failed. He brainstormed alternatives like a Wing Cap or Cloud Cap. He decided the Wing Cap would best serve the goal of opening up the level and creating a powerful gameplay contrast. He then began designing the specifics, such as how the player would acquire the cap and what the objective would be (eventually settling on flying through targets).
key_stories.outcome: Kaze decided to replace the restrictive mission with a new one centered on the Wing Cap. This new mission, available in a later act, will allow the player to fly freely across the entire level, enhancing the feeling of freedom through contrast with earlier, more grounded gameplay.
key_stories.key_quote: I think I much prefer that over the Paper Airplane. The question is just, what do we do with the Wing or the Cloud Camp?

key_stories.title: Modeling the Perfect Paper Airplane
key_stories.summary: When in need of a paper airplane model, Kaze rejected inaccurate digital versions. He proceeded to fold a real one for reference and then meticulously recreated it in 3D, demonstrating his commitment to authenticity and his unique, hands-on problem-solving process.
key_stories.challenge: The game needed a 3D model of a paper airplane for a mission, but Kaze was unsatisfied with existing references and a community-submitted model, finding them geometrically inaccurate to how a real plane is folded.
key_stories.process: Frustrated with digital references, Kaze left his desk to find a piece of graph paper. He returned and folded a real paper airplane live on stream for reference. He then meticulously recreated the object in Blender, using mathematical calculations and precise geometric manipulations to simulate the folds, rather than just approximating the shape. Finally, he created a custom texture for it.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze successfully created a highly accurate 3D model of a paper airplane, complete with a custom graph paper texture. He was very satisfied with the result, which looked authentic down to the folds.
key_stories.key_quote: I'm about to just get a piece of paper myself and make one. I can't stand this. I'm making a paper airplane to look at it.
